meanings.definition: Aligning or adjusting (an optical or other instrument) so that its parts are in proper relation to each other
meanings.sent1: She spent hours collimating the telescope to make sure it would show clear images.
meanings.sent2: The mechanic had to collimate the car's headlights to ensure they were pointing in the right direction.
meanings.sent3: The scientist joked that collimating the microscope was like solving a puzzle.
meanings.sent4: He thought of collimating the camera as aligning puzzle pieces to create a perfect picture.
meanings.sent5: Collimating the laser beam was crucial for the experiment to work properly.

meanings.definition: To make parallel or bring into line
meanings.sent1: The carpenter was collimating the edges of the wood to ensure they would fit together perfectly.
meanings.sent2: The teacher asked the students to collimate their desks in a straight row.
meanings.sent3: The chef humorously compared collimating the vegetables to lining up soldiers for battle.
meanings.sent4: She imagined collimating the books on the shelf as organizing an army in formation.
meanings.sent5: Collimating the fence posts made the garden look neat and tidy.

meanings.definition: To make (light or particles) parallel by using a collimator
meanings.sent1: The scientist was collimating the light beams to create a focused laser.
meanings.sent2: The technician was collimating the particles to ensure accurate measurements.
meanings.sent3: The magician playfully said he was collimating the magic sparks for his next trick.
meanings.sent4: She described collimating the sunlight as gathering rays into a single beam.
meanings.sent5: Collimating the flashlight beam made it shine brightly in the dark room.
